No "banks have I furnish'd with bees,</br>Whose murmur invites one to sleep,</br>No grottoes well shaded by trees,</br>Or hills all white over with sheep:"</br>The youth who these treasures possest,</br>These treasures would gladly resign—</br>Would hail himself happy, and blest,</br>To possess such a treasure as mine!

Yet Nature to none is unkind:</br>The shade of the wild-spreading tree,</br>The fragrance that floats in the wind,</br>And the sunshine, are treasures to me:</br>Then, the nightingales' notes are as sweet,</br>As soft flows the murmuring stream,</br>And the flocks do as tenderly bleat,</br>To me (tho' so poor) as to him.

For flowers, I've travers'd each field,</br>To deck my sweet Phillis's hair;</br>Not one the whole country can yield,</br>For Winter has lorded it there:</br>Yet will I not sigh at its reign,</br>For Winter has yielded a rose,</br>Whose beauty still charms the bleak plains,</br>And blossoms surrounded with snows.

—'Twas Phillis! — and this was the Morn</br>When first she inspir'd the air</br>Of the hills she was meant to adorn</br>With virtues so gentle and rare.</br>Ye shepherds, whom merit can move,</br>Let songs from the valley arise,</br>In praise of the charmer I love,</br>Till Echo reply from the skies.

For me, the dear charms of the maid</br>With rapture shall swell in my mirth,</br>Till the heart that shall dictate is laid,</br>Forgotten and silent, in dust!</br>She's fair, and I needs must admire,</br>Tho' I ever against it had strove;</br>She's true as my heart sould desire,</br>And my soul is devoted to love!</br>
